results.title: Looking for Signs That Apple’s Runaway Growth Is Waning
results.abstract: With iPhone sales projected to decelerate, investors will be scouring Apple’s earnings report on Tuesday for signs of how fast the company’s downshift is happening.

multimedia.caption: An Apple store in Manhattan. Some investors have begun to treat Apple as a “value” stock — reliable but no longer delivering runaway growth.
multimedia.copyright: Sam Hodgson for The New York Times

results.title: As Jack Dorsey Tries to Reshape Twitter, Revolving Door Takes Another Spin
results.abstract: The social networking company will undergo a major overhaul of its top ranks in the next few weeks, from its eight-member board to key executives in engineering and product.

multimedia.caption: Jack Dorsey, who was named Twitter’s permanent chief in October, has not been shy about making personnel changes.

results.title: Moving Your iTunes Library to a New Mac
results.abstract: Apple provides the software to move your files from an old Mac to a new one, but you need to provide the connection.

multimedia.caption: Apple’s Migration Assistant program, which is included in OS X, can transfer files and settings from one Mac to another.

results.title: Earnings, Earnings, Earnings
results.abstract: Strap in, it’ll be a busy week of technology news.

results.title: Despite Decades of Stealth, Sticking Points Bedevil F-35 Jet
results.abstract: As the price keeps rising for the Joint Strike Fighter, the world’s costliest weapon, the program has raised questions of whether it will ever be ready, or effective.
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

results.title: Europe’s Top Digital-Privacy Watchdog Zeros In on U.S. Tech Giants
results.abstract: Whether or not negotiators reach a pact by Feb. 1 on how companies like Google and Facebook use Europeans’ online data, Isabelle Falque-Pierrotin is in a position to propel privacy protection efforts.
org_facet: Commission Nationale de l'Informatique et des Libertes (CNIL)

multimedia.caption: Isabelle Falque-Pierrotin, empowered by Europe’s highest court, will be at the heart of efforts to police how digital data is transferred outside of the European Union.
multimedia.copyright: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times

results.title: Drone Lobbying Heats Up on Capitol Hill
results.abstract: The efforts in the halls of Congress are part of a multifront intervention by advocates for broader drone use as well as by their opponents, who argue that the machines pose significant safety and privacy risks.

multimedia.caption: The Inspire 1 drone by DJI. GoPro, DJI and other makers of recreational drones are lobbying against more regulations.

results.title: An App Helps Teachers Track Student Attendance
results.abstract: Kinvolved, whose users include a Harlem school, lets teachers take attendance and inform parents by text message if a student is absent or late.

results.title: France Plans a New Keyboard to Shift Control to Typists
results.abstract: The Azerty keyboard, whose shortcomings make it hard to type common characters, has never been standardized, and the Culture Ministry has asked for changes.

results.title: Google Pays Britain $185 Million to Settle Back Taxes
results.abstract: The technology giant says it will change how it calculates its tax payments in Britain so they are based on a percentage of local sales derived from the country.

results.abstract: Free Doritos don’t transform a workplace into a cool pad.

results.abstract: The president of Google for Work says it’s important to create a culture where people can present diverse points of view.

results.title: How Larry Page’s Obsessions Became Google’s Business
results.abstract: Mr. Page is hardly the first Silicon Valley chief with a case of intellectual wanderlust, but to a rare degree he has made his company a reflection of his personal fascinations.

results.title: Alphabet Close to Overtaking Apple as Most Valuable Company
results.abstract: Investors value the search firm’s earnings from fast-growing digital advertising twice as highly as Apple’s from a saturating smartphone market. They may be overlooking serious risks.

results.title: Storage of Records of Background Checks Shifted After Last Year’s Security Breach
results.abstract: A major component of the overhaul will be the creation of a new agency that will process federal background checks, called the National Background Investigations Bureau.

results.title: Older Drivers Hit the Road for Uber and Lyft
results.abstract: Seniors are turning to ride-sharing services for the extra income and flexibility they provide, but there are concerns about possible exploitation.

multimedia.caption: Carol Sue Johnson, 73, a driver for Uber, says her passengers run the gamut, but most of her earnings come from ferrying executives between the airport and major companies.

results.abstract: A high-profile former JPMorgan Chase executive has raised $52 million from several big banks for a start-up built on the technology underlying the Bitcoin virtual currency.

results.title: Where Wearable Technology Ends Up (Hint: Not Your Wrist)
results.abstract: Smartwatches, fitness trackers and other devices are supposed to better our lives, but the gadgets often sit idle and collect dust.

results.title: Jack Dorsey Juggles Twitter and Square, Both Caught in Downdraft
results.abstract: The volatility of the companies’ shares have hit Jack Dorsey in the wallet. Twitter will report its earnings on Feb. 10, and Square will reveal its first public earnings in March.

multimedia.caption: Jack Dorsey’s two companies — Twitter, the social network, and Square, the mobile payments company — have been stung by market volatility.

results.title: Apps to Manage Passwords So They Are Harder to Crack Than ‘Password’
results.abstract: Evaluating the merits of Dashlane, 1Password, LastPass and other methods of keeping long lists of increasingly complex passwords safe and accessible.

results.title: Video Feature: ‘Quantified Self’ Apps to Help Track Habits and Identify Patterns
results.abstract: As using technology to monitor sleep and other activities rises in popularity, these mobile applications can help you gather and assess this information.

results.title: Posting Animated GIFs on Facebook
results.abstract: GIFs cannot just be uploaded directly to Facebook. Instead, they need to be linked to from their location on the web.

results.title: Sticking With Windows 7
results.abstract: Microsoft has been enthusiastically recommending upgrading to its Windows 10 operating system. But what if you’d rather not?

results.title: Despite the CES Hype, It’s Better to Wait on That 4K TV
results.abstract: Advice for those thinking about buying a 4K television, also called Ultra HD, which has a higher resolution than the current high-definition 1080p TV sets.

multimedia.caption: Executive vice president at Samsung Electronics America, Joe Stinziano, presents the curved-screen Samsung KS9500 TV at the International CES in Las Vegas.

results.title: For Parental Controls, iPhones Beat Androids
results.abstract: The Apple phones were able to accomplish a range of restrictions, like blocking content and purchases, while Android phones offered incomplete solutions.

results.title: How to Track Data Use, and Choose the Right Smartphone Plan
results.abstract: Most smartphone plans either charge for overages or constrict data flow when limits are reached. So knowing how much one is consuming is crucial.

results.title: Amazon Prime Video, Home and Away
results.abstract: Access to Amazon Instant Videos can be gained in many ways, including via game consoles and devices that connect to your TV set.
